thread.title: Aust market rises as Greeks accept bailout
thread.title_full: Aust market rises as Greeks accept bailout

title: Aust market rises as Greeks accept bailout
text:
Thu, Jul 16, 2015, 11:52 AM AEST - Australia Markets close in 4 hrs 8 mins Aust market rises as Greeks accept bailout AAP – 48 minutes ago Print 
The Australian share market has opened more than half a per cent higher in the wake of Greece accepting tough new austerity measures. 
Patersons Securities senior adviser Marcus Padley said the Greek parliament's overwhelming vote in support of bailout conditions from its European creditors provided relief for the local market. 
"The decision in Athens will have helped everything along," Mr Padley said. 
"It should prompt investors to press the `buy' button on a number of stocks." 
Mr Padley said falls in the resources sector were unlikely to have a major negative impact on trading, with BHP Billiton down after flagging a $US2.8 billion hit to its full-year earnings on Wednesday and Rio Tinto lowering its full-year iron ore guidance on Thursday. 
"I expect resources to be a relegated to a side issue as the rest of the market continues to trade positively." 
Overseas, US stocks finished modestly lower amid uncertainty around the Greek decision and Chinese markets fell a second consecutive day. 
Mr Padley said falls in the key overseas markets were also unlikely to force the ASX down. 
Resources stocks were down in early trade with BHP Billiton losing 14 cents, or 0.52 per cent, to $26.76, while Rio Tinto fell 22 cents, or 0.41 per cent, to $52.90, and Fortescue dipped 3.5 cents, or 1.97 per cent, to $1.74. 
Among the big banks, Commonwealth was 81 cents higher at $87.93, Westpac was up 21 cents at $34.21, National Australia Bank gained 40 cents to $34.18 and ANZ added 32 cents to $32.74. 
KEY FACTS 
* AT 1015 AEST, the benchmark S&P/ASX200 index was up 38.4 points, or 0.68 per cent, at 5674.6 points. 
* The broader All Ordinaries index was higher 37.1 points, or 0.66 per cent, at 5656.1 points. 
* The September share price index futures contract gained 31 points to 5615 points, with 9,824 contracts traded. 
* At 1040 AEST, national turnover was 451 million securities worth $1.02 billion. @y7finance on Twitter, become a fan on Facebook Woodside revenue cut almost in half AAP
